titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Isaac Matthews Bray (1840-1896) was the captain of the Mary L. Cushing which was built at Newburyport by John E. Currier. The 220 foot long barque, was named after the wife of John Cushing, who had commissioned the vessel. The Mary L. Cushing was employed in general freighting from the US to Japan and India. It was sold in 1895 and was lost in the Pacific Ocean in 1905.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of log books of four ships: Mary L. Cushing (1888-1890), voyage from New York to Yokohama, Japan (a trip of 170 days) and from New York to Calcutta; SS City of Washington and SS Niagara (1893), for voyages between New York, Nassau, and Havanah; and the H.G. Johnson (1877-1880), voyages from New York to Melbourne, Hong Kong, and Shanghai, and from Philadelphia to Oregon and Queenstown. The collection also includes a 1874 letter from Isaac Bray to his sister Hannah, telling her of his appointment as captain of the Nearchus.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
